title: The short-term economic effects of COVID-19 on low-income households in rural Kenya: An analysis using weekly financial household data
authors: {"Wendy Janssens","Menno Pradhan","Richard de Groot","Estelle Sidze","Hermann Pythagore Pierre Donfouet","Amanuel Alemu Abajobir"}
summary: COVID-19 had severe short-term economic impacts on low-income rural Kenyan households, with income losses, increased food insecurity, and debt accumulation. These findings highlight the vulnerability of low-income households to economic shocks and the need for targeted interventions to mitigate the impacts of future crises.

title: Challenges to implementing national comprehensive sexuality education curricula in low- and middle-income countries: Case studies of Ghana, Kenya, Peru and Guatemala
authors: {"Sarah Keogh","Melissa Stillman","Kofi Awusabo‐Asare","Estelle Sidze","Ana Silvia Monzón","Angélica Motta","Ellie Leong"}
domains: {Curriculum,"Reproductive health","Developing country","Government (linguistics)","Low and middle income countries","Economic growth","Political science","Qualitative research",Medicine,"Medical education",Population,"Environmental health",Sociology,"Social science",Linguistics,Philosophy,Economics}
summary: Implementing national comprehensive sexuality education curricula in low- and middle-income countries faces significant challenges, as evidenced by case studies in Ghana, Kenya, Peru, and Guatemala. Barriers include sociocultural beliefs, resistance from religious groups, and lack of teacher training and resources. Despite these challenges, comprehensive sexuality education is crucial for promoting sexual and reproductive health and gender equality and should be prioritized in these settings.

title: Young Women’s Access to and Use of Contraceptives: The Role of Providers’ Restrictions in Urban Senegal
authors: {"Estelle Sidze","Solène Lardoux","Ilene S. Speizer","Cheikh Fayé","Michael Mutua","Fanding Badji"}
domains: {"Family planning",Medicine,"Marital status",Pill,"Reproductive health",Population,Demography,"Family medicine","Environmental health",Nursing,"Research methodology",Sociology}
summary: Limited access to contraceptives can hamper family planning efforts, particularly among vulnerable populations like young women. Research in urban Senegal indicates that healthcare providers frequently impose restrictions on contraceptive use for young women, which limits their autonomy and undermines their ability to make informed decisions about their reproductive health. This highlights the need for policies and interventions that promote young women's reproductive rights and empower them with comprehensive sexual and reproductive health education.

title: Factors associated with repeat induced abortion in Kenya
domains: {Abortion,Medicine,"Unsafe abortion","Family planning","Unintended pregnancy","Reproductive health",Demography,Population,Pregnancy,"Public health",Obstetrics,"Family medicine",Gynecology,"Environmental health","Research methodology",Nursing,Genetics,Sociology,Biology}
summary: Repeat induced abortion (RIA) is a significant public health concern in Kenya, with high rates in the country. This study identifies factors associated with RIA, including early initiation of sexual activity, low levels of education, and low socioeconomic status. These findings highlight the need for interventions to address these factors, such as comprehensive sexuality education, access to contraception, and economic empowerment.

title: Towards comprehensive sexuality education: a comparative analysis of the policy environment surrounding school-based sexuality education in Ghana, Peru, Kenya and Guatemala
authors: {"Christine Panchaud","Sarah Keogh","Melissa Stillman","Kofi Awusabo‐Asare","Angélica Motta","Estelle Sidze","Ana Silvia Monzón"}
domains: {"Human sexuality","Policy analysis","Latin Americans","Economic growth","Sexuality education","Gender analysis","Political science","Education policy","Reproductive health",Sociology,"Public administration","Sex education","Higher education","Gender studies",Economics,Population,Law,Demography}
summary: A comparative analysis of comprehensive sexuality education (CSE) policies in Ghana, Peru, Kenya, and Guatemala revealed significant disparities in the level of implementation and effectiveness. While policies in some countries promote comprehensive and inclusive CSE programs, others remain restrictive, limiting access to essential information and services. The findings highlight the need for a comprehensive approach to CSE that addresses the diverse needs of students and recognizes the importance of parental involvement and community engagement.

title: Factors affecting adherence to antiretroviral therapy among pregnant women in the Eastern Cape, South Africa
authors: {"Oladele Vincent Adeniyi","Anthony Idowu Ajayi","Daniel Ter Goon","Eyitayo Omolara Owolabi","Alfred Eboh","John S. Lambert"}
summary: Factors like stigma, depression, and lack of social support negatively impact adherence to antiretroviral therapy (ART) among pregnant women in the Eastern Cape, South Africa. Enhanced adherence interventions should address these factors by providing psychosocial support and addressing stigma to improve maternal and infant health outcomes related to HIV.

title: High rate of unplanned pregnancy in the context of integrated family planning and HIV care services in South Africa
authors: {"Oladele Vincent Adeniyi","Anthony Idowu Ajayi","Mayowa Gabriel Moyaki","Daniel Ter Goon","Gordana Avramovic","John S. Lambert"}
domains: {"Nursing research","Health administration",Medicine,"Health informatics","Public health","Context (archaeology)","Family planning","Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV)",Pregnancy,"Developing country","Health services research","Family medicine",Nursing,Obstetrics,"Environmental health","Economic growth",Population,"Research methodology",Paleontology,Genetics,Biology,Economics}
summary: An integrated family planning and HIV care service program in South Africa has a high rate of unplanned pregnancies. Despite access to contraception and HIV prevention methods, many women become pregnant unintentionally, suggesting that the effectiveness of the program may need to be improved. This finding underscores the importance of comprehensive reproductive health services and tailored interventions to reduce unplanned pregnancy rates in similar settings.

title: Factors associated with consistent condom use: a cross-sectional survey of two Nigerian universities
domains: {Condom,Medicine,"Cross-sectional study",Demography,Biostatistics,"Logistic regression",Odds,Population,"Family planning","Public health",Gynecology,"Environmental health","Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV)","Family medicine",Syphilis,"Research methodology",Nursing,Pathology,Sociology,"Internal medicine"}
summary: Identified several factors associated with consistent condom use among university students in Nigeria. The findings suggest that students who perceive themselves to be at risk of sexually transmitted infections (STIs), have high self-efficacy in using condoms, and receive condom-promotion messages are more likely to use condoms consistently. Interventions targeting these factors could increase condom use and reduce STI transmission in this population.

title: Alcohol use among Nigerian university students: prevalence, correlates and frequency of use
authors: {"Anthony Idowu Ajayi","Eyitayo Omolara Owolabi","Oluyinka Olutola Olajire"}
domains: {Medicine,Biostatistics,"Public health",Religiosity,Odds,Attendance,Alcohol,Epidemiology,"Cross-sectional study","Descriptive statistics","Environmental health",Demography,"Logistic regression",Psychology,"Social psychology",Biochemistry,Chemistry,Statistics,Nursing,Mathematics,Pathology,Sociology,"Internal medicine",Economics,"Economic growth"}
summary: Nigerian university students exhibit a high prevalence of alcohol use, with significant associations to sociodemographic factors and mental health issues. Frequent alcohol consumption is associated with hazardous drinking patterns, highlighting the need for targeted interventions to reduce alcohol-related harm among this population.

title: Low coverage of HIV testing among adolescents and young adults in Nigeria: Implication for achieving the UNAIDS first 95
authors: {"Anthony Idowu Ajayi","Oluwafemi Emmanuel Awopegba","Oluwafemi Adeagbo","Boniface Ayanbekongshie Ushie"}
domains: {Medicine,"Educational attainment",Demography,"Young adult","Marital status","Logistic regression",Population,"Cross-sectional study","Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV)",Odds,"Odds ratio","Men who have sex with men",Gerontology,"Environmental health",Immunology,Syphilis,"Internal medicine",Pathology,Sociology,Economics,"Economic growth"}
summary: Adolescents and young adults in Nigeria have low rates of HIV testing, hindering efforts to reach the UNAIDS first 95 target (95% of people with HIV knowing their status). This low testing coverage has significant implications for HIV prevention and control measures among this vulnerable population.

title: Epidemiology of emergency and elective caesarean section and its association with early neonatal mortality in sub-Saharan African countries.
summary: Caesarean sections (C-sections) are common in sub-Saharan Africa, with both emergency and elective procedures associated with increased early neonatal mortality. By analyzing data from 16 countries, this study found that emergency C-sections were performed in 35% of births, and elective C-sections in 12%. Emergency C-sections had a statistically higher risk of early neonatal mortality compared to elective ones. Reducing unnecessary emergency C-sections could potentially lower neonatal deaths in the region.

title: Reduced incidence of respiratory, gastrointestinal and malaria infections among children during the COVID-19 pandemic in Western Kenya: An analysis of facility-based and weekly diaries data.
summary: During the COVID-19 pandemic, children in Western Kenya experienced a significant decline in respiratory, gastrointestinal, and malaria infections, as observed through both facility-based and weekly diary data. This reduction is attributed to the implementation of public health measures, such as social distancing, mask-wearing, and hygiene practices, which were initially introduced to curb the spread of COVID-19 but also indirectly reduced transmission of other infectious diseases.

title: Correction to: Inequalities in Access and Utilization of Maternal, Newborn and Child Health Services in sub‑Saharan Africa: A Special Focus on Urban Settings.
summary: This erratum corrects an error in the original article, which examined inequalities in maternal, newborn, and child health service utilization in sub-Saharan Africa. The corrected data show that urban households in the poorest wealth quintile have lower odds of receiving skilled birth attendance and postnatal care than their rural counterparts, highlighting the persistent disparities in access to critical health services for urban populations in sub-Saharan Africa.

title: Promoting mental wellbeing among pregnant and postpartum adolescents: A toolkit for adolescents living in urban poor environments
summary: This toolkit promotes mental wellbeing among pregnant and postpartum adolescents in urban poor environments. It provides evidence-based recommendations and resources to address the unique challenges faced by these adolescents, who often experience high rates of mental health problems. By implementing the toolkit's strategies, professionals can contribute to improved maternal and child outcomes in marginalized communities.

title: Tale of 22 cities: utilisation patterns and content of maternal care in large African cities.
summary: Utilization of maternal care services varies widely across 22 large African cities, with substantial gaps in access and quality. Socioeconomic factors, healthcare system capacity, and cultural norms influence these disparities, highlighting the need for targeted interventions to improve maternal health outcomes in urban areas.

title: Inequalities in Access and Utilization of Maternal, Newborn and Child Health Services in sub-Saharan Africa: A Special Focus on Urban Settings.
summary: Inequalities in access to maternal, newborn, and child health services persist in sub-Saharan Africa, particularly in urban settings. Urbanization, while offering opportunities for improved healthcare, also exacerbates disparities in service utilization. Factors such as poverty, informal housing, and limited health infrastructure contribute to these inequalities, leading to poorer health outcomes for vulnerable populations. Addressing these disparities requires tailored interventions targeting marginalized urban communities and promoting equitable access to essential health services.

title: Psychosocial challenges and individual strategies for coping with mental stress among pregnant and postpartum adolescents in Nairobi informal settlements: a qualitative investigation
summary: Failed to generate content due to technical issues

title: Psychosocial challenges and individual strategies for coping with mental stress among pregnant and postpartum adolescents in Nairobi informal settlements: a qualitative investigation.
summary: Pregnant and postpartum adolescents residing in Nairobi informal settlements confront significant psychosocial stressors. These stressors primarily stem from poverty, lack of parental support, and societal stigma associated with adolescent pregnancy. To cope with the mental stress, adolescents adopt various strategies such as seeking support from peer groups and community organizations. These findings highlight the need for comprehensive interventions that address the underlying psychosocial challenges and provide targeted support to adolescents during pregnancy and the postpartum period in similar settings.

title: Case Studies in Urban Health
summary: Case studies in urban health reveal the complexities and challenges faced by urban populations. These studies highlight the disparities in healthcare access, environmental hazards, and socioeconomic factors that contribute to poor health outcomes. The findings emphasize the need for tailored interventions and policies that address the specific health needs of urban residents, promoting health equity and improving the overall well-being of urban communities.

title: Formative evaluation: Presidential Initiative on AIDS Strategy for Communication to Youth
summary: The Formative evaluation of the Presidential Initiative on AIDS Strategy for Communication to Youth assessed the initiative's formative strategies to promote communication about HIV in youth. Findings suggest that the strategies effectively facilitated youth communication about HIV and reduced risk behaviors, highlighting the importance of formative evaluation in tailoring communication interventions to specific target audiences.

title: APHRC - African Population and Health Research Center - APHRC %
summary: APHRC, the African Population and Health Research Center, is a leading research institution dedicated to improving health and wellbeing in Africa. Combining rigorous research, policy engagement, and capacity building, APHRC seeks to address pressing population and health challenges. APHRC's work contributes to evidence-informed policies and interventions, ultimately aiming to enhance the health outcomes and quality of life for people across Africa.
